questions.guidance_text: Enter your company's legal name as registered with the Ministry of Corporate Affairs. This ensures the policy covers the correct legal entity and claims are legally valid.
Your 15-digit GST number validates your business registration and helps determine the applicable tax on your insurance premium. This must match your official GST certificate.
Your company's 10-character PAN is required for regulatory compliance and tax documentation. This helps insurers verify your business identity with government databases.

Provide the complete address of the facility to be insured against pollution liability. This is the physical location where your operations that could cause pollution are conducted. Include plot number, industrial area, city, state, and pincode.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Plot No. 45, Phase II, MIDC Industrial Area, Taloja, Navi Mumbai, Maharashtra - 410208

questions.guidance_text: Name of the senior executive responsible for environmental compliance and insurance matters. This person will be contacted for all policy-related queries, claims, and regulatory matters.
Job title of the contact person, preferably someone in environmental, safety, or senior management role. This helps insurers understand the authority level for decision-making.
10-digit mobile number for urgent communications regarding pollution incidents, claims, or regulatory compliance matters. This number should be accessible 24/7 for emergencies.
Official email for receiving policy documents, compliance updates, and claim forms. Use an email that is monitored by multiple team members to ensure timely responses.
Select your primary business activity as it determines the type and level of pollution risks. Different industries have varying exposure to air, water, and soil contamination liabilities.
Describe your specific operations, especially aspects that could cause environmental pollution. Include details about raw materials used and waste generated.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Battery Recycling and Lead Recovery

questions.guidance_text: Provide a comprehensive description of your manufacturing or operational processes, especially those involving chemicals, emissions, or waste generation. This helps insurers understand your specific pollution risks and design appropriate coverage.
questions.placeholder: e.g., We manufacture industrial adhesives using organic solvents. The process involves mixing, heating, and packaging. We generate liquid waste treated in our ETP and air emissions controlled by scrubbers.

questions.guidance_text: Your company's total annual revenue helps insurers assess business size and determine appropriate liability limits. Larger operations typically need higher coverage limits due to greater exposure.
How long your facility has operated at this location. Longer operational history may indicate accumulated contamination risks, while newer facilities might have better pollution controls.
Provide your facility's total area in acres or square meters. Larger sites may have more potential for contamination spread but also better buffer zones from neighboring properties.
Count all buildings and structures on site including production units, warehouses, storage areas, and treatment facilities. Multiple structures may indicate diverse pollution sources.

Select all types of areas surrounding your facility within 1 km radius. Proximity to sensitive receptors like residential areas, water bodies, or schools significantly impacts your liability exposure.

Maximum amount the insurer will pay for all pollution claims during the policy period. Consider cleanup costs, third-party damages, legal fees, and regulatory fines when setting this limit. Higher risk operations need higher limits.
Date when pollution liability coverage should begin. Consider aligning with your environmental compliance calendar or fiscal year for easier management.
Pollution liability policies are typically annual but can extend to 3 years. Longer terms may offer premium savings and protection against rate increases.

Select all coverage types needed based on your operations. Sudden pollution covers accidents like spills, while gradual covers slow leaks. On-site cleanup is for your property, off-site for contamination that spreads beyond your boundaries.

The deductible is the amount you pay before insurance coverage kicks in. Higher deductibles reduce premiums but increase your out-of-pocket costs for claims. Choose based on your financial capacity. You can enter the amount in lakhs or crores (e.g., 50,00,000 or 5,00,00,000).

Select all environmental infrastructure at your site. Storage tanks and waste areas are high-risk features that need special attention in coverage. Proper containment systems may qualify for better rates.

Select all environmental safety measures implemented. Strong environmental management systems demonstrate risk awareness and can significantly reduce premiums. ISO certification is particularly valued by insurers.

questions.question_text: Do you currently have Pollution Liability Insurance?
questions.guidance_text: Having current or past pollution insurance shows risk awareness and responsibility. Continuous coverage often qualifies for better rates and retroactive date benefits.
Provide current insurer name, policy number, coverage limit, and expiry date. Include the retroactive date if applicable, as this determines coverage for past pollution that manifests later.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Insurer: United India, Policy: ENV/2024/12345, Limit: ₹5 Cr, Expiry: 31/03/2025, Retroactive: 01/04/2020

questions.question_text: Any Pollution Claims in Past 5 Years?
questions.guidance_text: Declare all pollution-related claims, whether paid by insurance or self-funded. Claims history affects premium but non-disclosure can void your policy. Include regulatory actions even if no claim was filed.
For each claim provide: date, type of pollution, cause, damage extent, claim amount, and remediation measures taken. Include steps taken to prevent recurrence.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Date: 15/06/2022, Type: Wastewater discharge, Cause: ETP malfunction, Amount: ₹25,00,000, Action: Upgraded ETP with backup systems

questions.guidance_text: Declare any environmental incidents even if they didn't result in claims or regulatory action. This includes minor spills cleaned internally. Transparency helps get accurate coverage.

questions.question_text: Any Site Contamination or Cleanup Activities?
questions.guidance_text: Declare if your site has known contamination or if you've conducted environmental remediation. Pre-existing contamination may need special coverage terms or exclusions.

questions.question_text: Any Environmental Fines or Legal Actions in Last 5 Years?
questions.guidance_text: Include all regulatory actions like Pollution Control Board notices, NGT orders, closure notices, or fines. Even resolved matters must be disclosed as they indicate compliance history.
Describe each regulatory action: issuing authority, date, violation type, penalty amount, and corrective actions taken. Include current compliance status and any pending matters.
questions.placeholder: e.g., CPCB Notice dated 10/01/2023 for exceeding emission limits, Fine: ₹5,00,000, Installed new scrubbers, Compliance achieved on 15/03/2023

questions.question_text: Do You Send Waste Off-site for Disposal?
questions.guidance_text: If waste leaves your premises for treatment or disposal, you may be liable for contamination at disposal sites. This includes hazardous and non-hazardous waste sent to authorized facilities.

questions.question_text: Use Third-party Carriers for Hazardous Materials?
questions.guidance_text: Using external transporters for chemicals or hazardous waste creates liability during transit. Ensure your policy covers transportation pollution if you use third-party carriers.
If you transport chemicals or waste in company vehicles, you need coverage for spills during transportation. This is especially important for inter-facility transfers.

List major chemicals and hazardous materials used in your operations with approximate quantities. Include CAS numbers if available. This helps insurers understand the severity of potential pollution events.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Sulfuric Acid (CAS: 7664-93-9) - 100 MT/month, Toluene (CAS: 108-88-3) - 50 MT/month, Heavy Fuel Oil - 200 KL/month

questions.guidance_text: Provide any additional information about your environmental risks, upcoming regulatory changes, planned facility improvements, or specific coverage concerns not addressed in previous questions.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Planning to install solar power and reduce emissions by 30% next year; Participating in responsible care program

questions.guidance_text: Upload facility layout showing production areas, storage locations, treatment systems, and proximity to sensitive areas. Visual documentation helps insurers assess risk accurately.
Upload your Environmental Clearance from MoEF or State authorities. Valid clearances demonstrate regulatory compliance and may qualify for better premium rates.
Upload valid Consent to Operate from State Pollution Control Board covering air and water emissions. Current CTO is essential for policy issuance for most insurers.
If you generate hazardous waste, upload authorization from SPCB under Hazardous Waste Rules. This document validates your waste management compliance.
Upload your current or most recent pollution liability policy. This helps insurers understand your existing coverage and offer appropriate renewal terms.
Upload recent environmental audit or compliance reports. Third-party audits showing good compliance can significantly improve your premium rates.
